campaign.story:
I shitpost a lot. That's the first thing you need to know. The second thing you need to know is this sometimes gets me in trouble, but it has also earned me a number of friends.
Not too long ago, I was musing aloud on Twitter as I so often do. What could I do for ZineQuest 2 that would be fun, easy, and coincide with my existing plans for 2020? So I threw an idea out into the void: Drunk History but game designers talking about their life. Figured nobody would respond, or they'd laugh and it'd go nowhere.
I was wrong.
People started volunteering. Just a few at first. Then more. Then I was in trouble. Because you see I have this deal with myself. If I make a shitpost and people respond positively enough, I make it a legitimate project.
Me (Joe DeSimone) [He/Him] - The Interviewer and an Absolute Fool
I've made a moderately successful career around games over the years by following essentially only this rule. I've designed educational games for companies because I joked it couldn't be done. I endlessly tweeted at the co-founder of my favorite publisher at the time and it ultimately led to my first editing job in the industry, and a $40K Kickstarter, because a friend said it was a terrible idea. I started a game design learning center and run curricular design there because of this rule. This is how my life evolved. Now there's this.
Now there's Not Pretty But Wonderful.
Here's the cover. Jordan Shiveley (@HottestSingles) did me a solid with it.
I want to be very clear: this book is getting written whether or not this Kickstarter funds. I plan on interviewing people one way or another. I will be attending conventions no matter what. But I'd like the wider hobby to be a part of this effort. I want to share my absurdist shitpost writ large. Because I think it will be a fun time for all those who give themselves over to the idea, and I don't think that should be limited to myself and my friends in the industry. I think that fun should include you.
But what is it EXACTLY?
Firstly, it's a book. It's not a game. But it's a book about games and the people who make them. Every $75 raised will secure one interview with one designer. I will meet up with them at a convention somewhere in the world and then spend up to $50 on alcohol, food, or caffeine for them. They will consume it in a sitting, and then we will chat for an hour or so. I will record this and then I will transcribe it. You will get to read what comes out of their mouth.
Secondly, it's an excuse for those people to let loose. Go a little wild at the conventions where I'll see them. Because for many of these people, conventions are work. That sucks. Conventions are glorious celebrations of our collective love of games. This is an hour or so where they get to muse and ramble and joke about that.
Basically how I've approached the people involved with this project. Also me when people ask if this will be a serious, professional endeavor.
But what will the CONTENTS be like? Racy? Funny? Horrifying?
I don't know! That's the fun of it. All of the above? None of them? Probably somewhere between those two extremes. If you want to see a sample of what the contents of the book might look like, well... I've got an entire hour of interview audio and a transcript already prepared. Enjoy! You can find bios of my lovely guinea pigs at the bottom of this page. I have absolutely no idea if this will be representative of any other interview. Let's find out!
This book will be done as a PDF and as a Print-On-Demand (POD) text. If you back at a level that gets you the POD, you will be emailed an at-cost discount coupon for one copy upon completion of the text. I may also make an e-reader version of the book. I honestly don't know. Fair warning.
Here's what it could wind up looking like. Who knows?! Thanks to Adam Vass for this mockup!
But isn't drinking wrong at conventions?
No and also fuck off. I've been sober for nearly seven years. Several of the people I'm interviewing are as well. The alcohol isn't the point. Whether it's John "Hambone" McGuire getting real weird with a bunch of meat, or Mark Richardson drinking seltzer, or Fiona Maeve Geist getting well and truly obliterated... well, that's just how they're getting to a place where they can be goofy, unrestrained, and open. What's the old refrain?
Image by Adam Ellis from his webcomic Books of Adam (02/03/16)
What safety and sensitivity measures will be in place?
Safety will come down to self-control, ultimately. I don't intend to infantilize anyone. I'll be doing some basic drink counting and if people go overboard I will put them in a cab back to their hotel. If they ask, I will accompany them and stay as they sober up. That's about it.
Sensitivity is something I'm treating more rigorously. I've lined up sensitivity readers from Overeaters Anonymous, Alcoholics Anonymous, and Narcotics Anonymous who feel comfortable enough in their sobriety to handle reading the transcriptions. For (I hope) obvious reasons, I will not be breaking their anonymity.
So who are these creators I keep referencing? Here's the list so far (alphabetically):
Further down the page is more information on each of these lovely humans. For now, just know that not every person here will necessarily be included in the book. That will come down to funding. I'm looking for $1500 to get this kicked off; that will cover the first 10 of 32 people on the list.  Every $75 raised after that will secure another creator. This will cover Kickstarter fees, taxes, and me spending $50 on each interviewee for consumables of their choice. If you really, desperately want to see a particular creator included, back this KS at their "Oh no, [XXX]" pledge level. That immediately shoots them to the front of the list.
Pledge levels? What are those? Are they important?
YEP! Definitely should've mentioned those earlier. Thankfully they're not too complicated (and there's only a handful despite looking like dozens).
This is your entry level pledge, and the one I expect most people to back at. It gets you the PDF of the finished product somewhere near the end of 2020 or beginning of 2021. You can read these on a sitting computer or a handheld computer or even print them out and make your own pretend book. I don't care!
Slightly better! If you want a book that's bound by a company and not with duct tape from your garage, this is the pledge level for you. You'll get the PDF as above, but you'll also get an at-cost coupon for a softcover Print-On-Demand (POD) version of the book from DriveThruRPG.com. You can redeem this coupon whenever you want and they'll send the book to your house for the cost of shipping! Magic!
Hooo boy now we're talking. You get everything as above (PDF + POD), but now the book is hardcover! Also you get to ask one question to one creator. Which creator? I GET TO PICK! You gotta drop the really big bucks if you want that kind of control over your life. But your question will be included in the interview, and thus in the book, as either one I legitimately ask or (if it's wildly inappropriate) one that the creator and I mock viciously. TBH both sound fun.
Basically paying your way into the Ivy League but more useful for your prospects in the games industry. This is the big kahuna, the pièce de résistance. This is the level where shit really slaps. Where it absolutely does fuck. If you give me fifty whole dollars, you'll get a hardcover book, get to ask three questions, pick the creator who gets asked them, and I drop your name in the interview. Your name gets said aloud to someone you admire (or maybe hate!). Think about the power you'll wield. Unlimited power.
You're just toying with me (or you're my parents). Why would you pay $150 for this? But hey. Not gonna NOT take your money, right? At this level, one of the creators asks ME a question of your choosing. I have to answer it. Rigorously. Honestly. I mean, it could be anything. You could really mess up my life. $150 is actually kinda cheap for the power to ruin a life. If I weren't running this KS, I might pledge here. Damn.
Where will the money really be going? What are the Stretch Goals?
No lie, that's the whole shebang. I'm not looking to profit off of this campaign. Making the PDF will be easy enough, and handling book printing via POD is likewise inexpensive for me. My costs are booze, taxes, KS fees, travel, and lodging. The basic thrust of this campaign is the whole damn thing.
But if you want it laid out for you.
(1) $50 will go toward every creator I interview, which will be used for alcohol, food, or caffeine that they must consume while we are talking.
(2) Every $500-$1000 after the initial funding goal will see me attend another convention somewhere in the world and find a minimum of one new person to interview. This interview will of course be included in the book.
(3) If we hit $2500, I will hire Mary Georgescu to do layout on the book.
(4) If we hit some huge amount - tens of thousands of dollars - I will shut down this KS. I don't need that heat in my life.
That's it. That's the whole campaign. Below are some further bios of lovely people. I hope you think this dumb idea is as wonderful as I do, because I'd very much like to see this book made real and put into your hands.
Tracy Barnett (They/Them) is a queer game designer, editor, and podcaster. They've worked on Turn for Brie Beau Sheldon, Iron Edda Accelerated for Encoded Designs, and the forthcoming Descent Into Midnight in association with Riverhouse Games. You can find their games at theothertracy.itch.io and listen to them and Kate Bui on Another Blank Page.
Drinks: Beer, bourbon, scotch
Sharang Biswas (He/Him) is an NYC-based artist, game designer, and writer. He has won an IndieCade Award, two IGDN Indie-Groundbreaker Awards, and a Golden Cobra Award. He has exhibited games at art galleries, museums, and festivals, and was recently a visiting artist at the International Center of Photography. Sharang is currently working on the anthology Honey & Hot Wax: An Anthology of Erotic Art Games with Co-editor Lucian Kahn.
Drinks: Sweet, creamy, chocolaty drinks
Misha Bushyager (She/Her) is a longtime gamer and designer working to ensure the next generation of geeks sees themselves represented. She's a panelist, writer, editor, proofreader, and sensitivity editor for tabletop RPGs and LARPs. She's one of the founders of New Agenda Publishing and a curator for More Seats at the Table. She has worked on Orun, #Feminism, Fate of Cthulhu, Lovecraftesque, Dead Scare, Misspent Youth: Sell Out With Me, Masks: Unbound, and the as yet unpublished LARP Nightingales.
Drinks: Angry Orchard Crisp Apple, bourbon, ginger ale
Banana Chan (She/Her/They/Them) is an RPG designer, writer, and the owner of the boardgame publishing company, Game and a Curry. While most of her written work is either comedy, horror or a mix of both, she is most interested in ideas of identity, our identities in a digital age. Some of her work has been for games such as 7th Sea: Khitai, Kids on Bikes, Terror Below, and Warp's Edge.
Drinks: Anything you'd think a hipster would drink
Dave Cox (He/Him) is a designer and storyteller out of Southern Appalachia. He just finished-up A Rasp of Sand, his ZineQuest 1 entry, and loves using mechanics to promote storytelling. Mood is everything.
Drinks: Neat bourbon or an Aviation, if he's feeling fancy and can get it
Dennis Detwiller (He/Him) is a 29-year veteran of RPGs and card games whose works include Magic: The Gathering, Delta Green, GODLIKE, The Unspeakable Oath, and too many others to list. For 15-years he created video games including Hulk: Ultimate Destruction, Scarface: The World is Yours and [PROTOTYPE]. Dennis has won 13 ENnie awards and 4 Origins awards for gaming excellence and two of his products: Delta Green and Delta Green: COUNTDOWN are the #1 and #2 highest reviewed products of all time on RPGnet. But then again, the likes the movie THE CORE, so all bets are off.
Drinks: Guinness, straight vodka shots, sometimes tequila
Marie Enger (They/Them/She/Her) is a cartoonist and illustrator out of St. Louis. Enger is most known for self publishing the stoner horror Fhtagn & Loathing, We Are In A Dark Place, Regolith, the dark occult western TTRPG Casket Land, and their three inktober projects: All Werewolves Must Go, Nosferatu!, and The Bones of this Place. YEAH they did those PUP comics! YES they did work for projects like Dept. H, Invader Zim, Rick and Morty, Adventure Time, and Rocko's Modern Life. They love punk music, Nosferatus, and birds.
Drinks: IPAs, whiskey, gin, cheap beer, weed!
Daniel D. Fox (He/Him) is the Executive Creative Director of Games at Andrews McMeel Universal. He was awarded two gold ENnies in 2018 for Best Game and Product of the Year with his dark fantasy hit Zweihänder Grim & Perilous RPG. After a 16 year career in digital advertising, Daniel now spends his days designing tabletop role-playing games and creating strategies to reach new RPG audiences. He enjoys good whiskey, Zweihänder, and Dungeons & Dragons.
Drinks: Sazerac, Negroni, Old Fashioned
Fiona Maeve Geist (She/Her) resides in WXXT country with her cat. She has appeared in varied venues including CLASH Media, Vastarian, Ashes and Entropy, Lovecraftian Proceedings, Lamplight, and Trans Studies Quarterly. She is primarily known for being a relentless editor and occasional writer of roleplaying games—including as a developer for the ENnie Award winning Mothership. Her RPG editing credits include: The Ultraviolet Grasslands, Mörk Börg, Through Ultan’s Door, Troika!, Libreté, and Silent Titans. Her game writing consists of Troikahearts, 📀🐴#1: Off to the Races, Labyrinth of Haunted Memory, and Rotten Sycamores. In a previous life she was an academic.
Drinks: Mezcal, corpse reviver with proper absinthe, single malt scotch, MD 20/20, Cisco
Liam Ginty (He/Him/They) is the designer behind Americana, Ego, The Boughs, and Broken Tartarus. He is also the project lead behind Roleplayer's Guide To Heists and Disposable Heroes. Writer, video producer, community organizer, and food aficionado. IRL Wizard of the Unbroken Moon.
Drinks: Weed, mushrooms, chocolate, Schneiders Honey Mustard Pretzels
JR Goldberg (He/Him) is a writer and game designer living in Philadelphia. He is probably best known for putting together Doikayt: A Jewish TTRPG Anthology. He writes a lot about professional wrestling. He still listens to folk punk even though he's in his mid thirties.
Drinks: Hamm's Beer, Fernet Branca
John R. Harness (He/Him) is an artist and independent curator in Chicago, IL. He created #SadMechJam and coined the phrase "lyric games." His game writing explores gay history and the epistemology of play.
Drinks: Homemade classic cocktails, cheap beer at metal concerts
James Mendez Hodes (He/Him) is a Filipino-American writer, game designer, and cultural consultant, from the greater New York metro. You may know him from his ENnie Award-winning work on role-playing games like 7th Sea and Scion, his blog where he makes fun of the children for whom he runs role-playing games, or his translation of Homer's Iliad into rap. His primary party role is tank, secondary support.
Drinks: Beer, shōchū, port, South African pinotage
Will Jobst (He/Him/They/Them) is a game designer, zinester, and musician living in Boston. They've been making games for a few years, including games like two hearts beat as one, Black Mass, and A Guide to Casting Phantoms in the Revolution. Will has been nominated Most Innovative for the Indie Groundbreakers by the Indie Game Developer Network.
Drinks: Ice coffee, black. "Boston Iced," an ice coffee when it's below freezing outside. If you live in Boston, you like the interiority of cold
Humza Kazmi (He/Him) is a partner with the Hydra Cooperative, an independent OSR publisher. He has worked on projects such as Operation Unfathomable, Misty Isles of the Eld, and Lorn Song of the Bachelor. Prior to his work with the Hydra Cooperative, Humza contributed to Mongoose's Paranoia (2004) line. He lives in the Washington, DC metro area, with a day job as an immigration attorney.
Drinks: Coffee, black
Daniel Kwan (He/Him) is an ENnie nominated podcaster, game designer, and educator based in Toronto. He is the co-host of Asians Represent on the One Shot Network and GM of the Dungeons & Da Asians actual play series. Daniel is one of the creators of Ross Rifles - a PbtA game set in the trenches of WWI - and one of the co-founders of Level Up Gaming, an organization that provides adults with autism and other disabilities opportunities to develop through tabletop gaming. Also, ya boy is gonna be writing for a new D&D 5E hardcover!
Drinks: I LOVE this Chinese drink called Jia Duo Bao
Noah Lloyd (He/Him/They/Them) is your androgynous-aspiring half-sibling who only wants to talk about David Bowie, Star Trek, and anti-capitalism. He freelances in copy-editing, scenario writing, and layout, but their true love is developmental editing; seeing a product go from first draft to finished product is a gift. He co-founded Reckoning of the Dead, a horror RPG blog, in 2017. Noah has also released a few micro-games, with more on the backburner. Currently, they’re a disillusioned PhD candidate in 18th-century literature, but he hopes to work in book publishing post-graduation.
Drinks: Whisky, martinis, the Kingston Soundsystem
Jayd Matyas (She/Her) is a multidisciplinary game designer with a background in industrial design and wearable tech. She's a co-director of Dames Making Games, a co-founder of the indie game studio Light Crumb, and a contributor to the podcast Asians Represent!. She currently works as a game designer at DeepMind in London, developing games for AI research.
Drinks: Pilsners, drier red wines like pinot noir, hot sake in the winter, cocktails with egg whites, herbal teas, sparking water
John "Hambone" McGuire (He/Him) is a podcast producer hailing from the Garden State of New Jersey. He is the co-host of The Vintage RPG Podcast and when he is not slingin’ dice he plays bass for an Outlaw Country band called Secret Country. He is also an Ares who likes small animals and a good mystery.
Drinks: Coffee, Coke Zero, Stewart’s Key Lime Soda
Éric Paquette (He/Him) is a convention organizer, podcaster, game designer, and public servant in Ottawa, Canada. He is one of the organizers of the games convention CanGames, which is Canada’s longest running games convention. He is a co-host of the Tome Show Book Club on the Tome Show Network. Éric dabbles in game design and is working on his first board game, Colombophilie: The Pigeon Racing Game.
Drinks: Iced tea, lemonade
Mark Richardson (He/Him) is a Canadian game designer and Ennie award winning cartographer. He's the creator of the Headspace RPG and did the cartography for both Seventh Sea 2E and Blue Planet: Recontact. His current project is Treads, a co-op board game where you drive a tank in WW2.
Drinks: Root beer, ginger beer, Dr. Pepper, tonic water and lime
Sean Richer (He/Him) has been a video game developer for 15 years; at this point he cares more to see a project cancelled vs. operating for too long. Musician, he puts microphones down his throat and howls in dark cement boxes. Recently into TTRPGs. Tentacles, aliens, surrealist memes, robots, bat gods, weapon satellites. And he cooks a lot. Grew up playing Rifts/Robotech. He just wants to make cool stuff. So far that includes Terror of the Stratosfied, Necrotic Edifices of Iron and Moon; The Depth of Time Untold, Upon the Metal River, Ever Shimmering They Are Hypnotic Shores. Soon it will also include Terror of the Stratosfiend 2.
Drinks: Anything with rum in it
Jared Sinclair (He/Him) is the author of lots of small art games, sundry elfgames material, and innumerable Twitter threads. He is the creator and sometimes writer of the pre-eminent RPG theory zine Anti-Sisyphus. He also likes Twin Peaks and Steely Dan.
Drinks: Negroni, Rhum, Yard Beer, Coffee
Chris Spivey (He/Him) is a game designer, line editor, and writer who brings his decades-old love of gaming, horror, and history, to his work in order to create a more inclusive gaming world. His groundbreaking and critically acclaimed game Harlem Unbound won 3 Gold Ennies and the IGDN Groundbreaker award. Some of his other contributions can be found in Cthulhu Confidential, 7th Sea: Land of Fire and Gold, Geist 2E, Trail of Cthulhu: Out of the Woods, and Thousand Years of Night. Future work includes Haunted West, Harlem Unbound 2E, and Masks of the Mythos.
Drinks: Lagavulin 16, Manhattan made with rye (up), coffee
Greg Stolze (He/Him) was the first person to use Kickstarter for tabletop roleplaying games and, if that's not enough to earn him your ire, he also bears some responsibility for Unknown Armies, Reign, and Termination Shock. He's been writing game stuff for money since (sigh) 1996.
Drinks: Gin & tonic, Moscow mule, Negroni?
Jeff Stormer (He/Him) is an award-nominated podcaster, game designer, eggnog enthusiast, and the (unofficial) official LARP designer of the Olive Garden restaurant. He hosts Party Of One, an actual play podcast focused on 2-player role-playing experiences, and All My Fantasy Children, a tabletop RPG-inspired podcast focused on worldbuilding and character creation. His RPG of super-spies and office meetings, Mission: Accomplished!, funded on KS in 2018. He spends his nights watching wrestling with his wife in West Philadelphia.
Drinks: Margaritas, sour beers
Aram Vartian (He/Him) is a producer, writer, designer, and recent Chicago transplant. He is the creator and editor of the actual play podcasts Rise of the Demigods and Godsfall, and is planning a modern-day superhero podcast called Eveolution Earth slated for late 2020.
Drinks: Old Fashioned, any milkshake with alcohol, iced mocha
Adam Vass (He/Him) is a musician, graphic designer, game designer, and publisher. He dropped out of college to be in a touring band at 19 and that somehow worked. Adam got his start as World Champ Game Co. self-publishing card games in 2016 but quickly transitioned to RPGs, where he's made titles like Babes in the Wood, All We Love We Leave Behind, Wish You Were Here, and more. More recently, he's been exploring the cross section of boardgames and RPGs, designing boxed projects with more tactile components and physical presence on a players’ table.
Drinks: Snooty black coffee, $5 pour over shit. Espresso, too. Cortados if the shop has oat milk
James Wallis (He/Him) ran Hogshead, published Nobilis, invented storygames (by accident), sank a thousand barges, held the Guinness world record for non-stop D&D (84 hours, it's in the 1987 book), wrote a history of board games for Dorling Kindersley, has played all the Spiel des Jahres winners in order, and once taught The Game to the listeners of BBC Radio 4. He lives in London with his wife and 1d4-1 children. He's also an official NPC in the Warhammer and Shadowrun universes.
Drinks: Cider
Darren Watts (He/Him) is the former President/owner of Hero Games and Indie Press Revolution, but got out of the owning things business a few years back and now freelances for games like Dr. Who and Sentinel Comics.
Drinks: Wine, rum, NO GIN!
Sam Webb (He/Him) is the Head of RPG development at British publisher Modiphius Entertainment as well as one half of the indie publisher Black Cats Gaming. He began tabletop roleplaying in his final year at drama college, where he studied to be a theatre director, and went on to organise and run successful live action role play events around the UK.
Drinks: Gin, beer, tequila, coffee
Joe Young (He/Him) is an award-winning game designer from Cincinnati, Ohio. Obsessed with jamming bleeding-edge mechanics into traditional frameworks, he enjoys destroying assumptions about what games can be, long walks in dark forests, and cooking with his partner.
Drinks: Beer (IPAs preferred, sours discouraged), Moscow mules, vodka tonics, absinthe
Joe DeSimone (He/Him) is the absolute clown behind this project. He's worked as a games educator and researcher for organizations such as E-Line Media, Brooklyn Game Lab, and Midnight Commercial, and has edited games such as Hyperlanes and Sleepaway. Currently he's serving as the Co-Founder and Lead Game Design Instructor at The Academy of Games in Austin. He's also had a bunch of other jobs, got some degrees, and done other shit he doesn't want to talk about.
Drinks: Coffee with cream, Arizona Green Tea, (formerly) Woodford Reserve bourbon.
Richard Ruane (He/Him) is a Brooklyn-based game designer, occasional grad student, and educational technology professional. A former editor for White Wolf Game Studio, he's the founder of R. Rook Studio and the creator of Dark Designs in Verdigris, Moonlight on Roseville Beach, Chronicles of the Spacejammer, and Barrow Keep. Find him at r-rook.itch.io.
Mary Georgescu (She/Her) is a Ridgewood, NY based game designer and freelancer who founded Haiduc LLC in 2018 to self-publish her ridiculous brand of bullshit. She is a graduate of the MFA Visual Narrative Program from the School of Visual Arts and a soon-to-be MFA graduate of the NYU Game Center.
Ray Olsen (He/Him) is a New York-based game designer currently working on Dream World Mercenaries. He is also part of an ongoing stream called Uncanny Adventures.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
People could die. I could die. Interviewees could die. The world could end. Also much less dire things could occur. People might drop out. Maybe this project is viciously dragged as tasteless and nobody wants to be associated with it. Beyond that, not really much. I'm going to interview my friends and buy them alcohol or other things. So long as they're still my friends, and I can still access a computer somewhere in the world, this thing is getting made.

updates.update_userinfo: The coming weeks and the beginning of transcription
updates.update_content:
Hey everybody,

So we're right on the cusp of ZQ3. I'm fine using an acronym there because, well, ya'll backed this during ZQ2. That means we're about a year out from when this whole thing kicked off. Could I be further along? Oh Hell yeah. But I'm not too mad. Given that this entire thing was fundamentally predicated on convention travel at first, pretty happy I've averaged roughly an interview every two weeks through the past year. It's certainly helped me stay sane.

updates.update_userinfo: Well it's been a hot minute
updates.update_content:
Here's the deal: I don't have any excuse. I burned out, work got insane, and quarantine finally got to me. But I could've written any number of messages between my last one and now. I just didn't. That sucks, and I'm sorry.

But I'm back! Got two interviews lined up for next week and then I'll be getting back on some kind of semblance of a schedule in 2021.

updates.update_userinfo: I FORGOT SOMETHING: Giving a talk on Narrative Board Games tonight (08/21)
updates.update_content:
Hey everybody,
This was supposed to be in the last update but I wrote and posted it late at night so it was forgotten. NONEPUB started yesterday (along with UK Games Expo, so it's a busy convention weekend). For those who don't know, NONEPUB is a playtesting convention for unpublished designers to get in front of established ones. There's also a panel track where people are giving talks on various topics. Well, this year I'm one of the speakers. I'll be giving a talk on Narrative in Board Games tonight at 3:30 PM PST // 5:30 PM CST // 6:30 PM EST with Julie Ahern, VP & COO of Greenbriar Games and Director-at-Large of the Game Manufacturers Association (GAMA). You can watch live on ! Hope to see you there.

Hey everybody,
It's been a minute. Well, it's been just over a month. I've lain fallow but, like the dawn, I emerge bearing gifts of new life. Next week is gonna be a good one.
On Wednesday 08/26 I'll be interviewing the incomparable Marie Enger at 5:00 PM PST // 7:00 PM CST // 8:00 PM EST. updates.update_userinfo: Things aren't improving so let's get this train moving
updates.update_content:
Hey everybody,
So I took a break. Initially because talking about games during a global upheaval just wasn't something I felt was appropriate, then because I went into quarantine thinking I had COVID-19. Thankfully I do not, which I was told eleven days after I got my test. That part is good, at least. Unfortunately, the world is still very much screwed up. So I guess let's assume that's the new normal for now and get back to talking about games!

Hey all,
Been a minute since the last update. I'm sorry about that. Just have not been in the headspace to do much of anything. I hope you understand, but even if you do I'm still sorry. You gave me money to make a thing happen. It's still happening. Just a little slower than I would've liked these past couple weeks.
In slightly better news, I have done a couple episodes since last we spoke. One was a bonus episode about game design education and running games online for kids - both topics close to my heart and especially important these days - and the other was with designer Dennis Detwiller (He/Him). The former is already up on the YouTube channel, and the latter will be up later tonight.

Hey all,
So I finally got around to putting that YouTube page together. The nine interviews I've done so far are all up on there now. Here's the link. They'll still be transcribed and laid out and put into a book and all that jazz, but if listening or watching is more your speed than reading... well, enjoy :)
We've also got another interview lined up for you tonight. Jared Sinclair (He/Him), the author of lots of small art games, sundry elfgames material, and innumerable Twitter threads, will be hopping on with me at 4:30PM PST // 6:30PM CST // 7:30PM EST // 12:30AM BST. Jared and I have been speaking a lot over the past few weeks of quarantine, so it should end up being a pretty casual conversation. Or not! We are both vicious shitposters and hecklers, so it could wind up being fairly brutal. Who knows?! Tune in!

project_data.project_name: Not Pretty But Wonderful: Designers In Conversation

campaign.story:
Rebel Crown is a tabletop roleplaying game of courtly intrigue, obsessive ambition, and perilous conflict. One player takes on the role of the Claimant, former heir to the throne who was betrayed by their family and robbed of their rightful titles. Others play their most stalwart allies: wise chancellor, devoted knight, idealistic noble, vengeful soldier, or opportunistic outlaw. Conflicting duties and ambitions will push them into points of tension, but their commitment to the Claimant’s ascent ties them together.
A GM plays the other inhabitants of the cursed and fractured Empire: nobles, commoners, outlaws, and undead wraiths. The GM presents opportunities, foreshadows consequences, and introduces adversity. They present the challenges that make the player characters’ fight for the throne uncertain and exciting. As a group, you play to find out whether the Claimant can take their throne and what sacrifices must be made along the way.
Rebel Crown is a Forged in the Dark game, building on the core system pioneered in John Harper’s Blades in the Dark. It leverages a resolution and advancement system that is character-driven and full of interesting compromises while developing a unique focus on character relationships and a finite campaign arc.
We have released a Quickstart version of the rules that you can print and play right now.  The Quickstart includes all the player sheets and a tense starting situation to kick off a one-shot or campaign.
It is the year 247 of the Aonaicthe Empire, a centralized dominion that brought three warring kingdoms into unsteady accord. The kingdoms assented (or succumbed) to Imperial rule only in the face of an existential threat: a curse fell upon the kingdoms and the souls of those who die do not remain at rest. Monstrous wraiths plague the Empire, bringing suffering and destruction. Nearly three hundred years of coping with this crisis has changed life in the Empire completely. Fear of wraiths has calcified the already entrenched feudal structure.
The three largest houses style themselves kings and queens under the Empress: the ancient house Lolaire, the wealthy house Darach, and the pious house Nathair. Every other house has sworn fealty to these three. The three kingdoms have a duty to maintain peace and control the unquiet dead within their own borders. Peace is maintained by the Empress’s might, and by the fear that open battle would doom the kingdoms to a pandemic of wraiths. Without the ability to mass armies in the field, ambitious nobles must turn to subtler methods. In this context, the Claimant seeks to reclaim their throne from their treacherous uncle. They must face rival houses, members of their own family, and spirits of the unquiet dead in a daring ascent to power.
Rebel Crown builds off the core framework of Blades in the Dark. This system is ideal for playing a connected group of characters with a shared ambition: in this case, the Claimant and the trusted members of their retinue. The resolution system provides constant dramatic momentum, as actions often succeed at the cost of introducing new challenges. This core system has proven a perfect fit for a game that is ultimately about an uncertain climb up the ladder of power.
The Playbooks in Rebel Crown are based on different approaches to the quest for the crown, and on the relationships between the player characters. A crucial part of gameplay (and character advancement) is the conflicting impulses of these characters, and the advice they give the Claimant to guide their ascent. The Playbook design produces characters that are both committed to a shared cause, and in conflict about the path to victory.
The Claimant is the heart of the campaign: the campaign ends in victory if they claim their crown; it ends in failure if they die. Play the Claimant if you want to support the other players at the table, pulling them into the spotlight, and digging into their characters’ beliefs.
The Devoted is a fierce warrior, utterly dedicated to the Claimant. They truly love the Claimant; though that love may be filial or romantic, reciprocated or not. Play the Devoted if you want to explore the tensions that arise when personal loyalty is placed above all else.
The Chancellor is a fellow member of the nobility, with greater experience and resources than the Claimant. Play the Chancellor if you want to play the mentor to another character and if you want to explore the tension between providing support and pushing for your own agenda.
The Idealist has allied with the Claimant because they believe it is a path to the greater good. They are committed to the Claimant, but equally committed to a cause: a vision of a more just kingdom. Play the idealist to explore how ideals can be compromised in becoming a reality, and if you want to play the conscience to another character.
The Outlaw is allied with the Claimant to gain a pardon and redeem their name. They have lived away from polite society for some time, surviving among the underworld of the Empire. Play the Outlaw if you want to emphasize the reality of feudal warfare outside the bounds of noble courts, and if you want to explore the tension between pragmatism and reputation.
The Vengeant once served another noble house but was cast out. They seek to bring their former masters low, and have joined the Claimant to see that done. Play the Vengeant if you want a strong relationship with your enemies and if you want to explore the toll that warfare takes in both victory and defeat.
Draft Character Sheets
The characters in Rebel Crown are not a loosely assembled party of adventurers: they are sworn allies on a deadly quest. A campaign of Rebel Crown drives hard toward this objective and may end in victory or defeat. If the Claimant takes the throne, the campaign succeeds and a brief epilogue details the ensuing years of rule. If the claimant dies, or abandons their quest, then the campaign ends in defeat. Nothing is certain ahead of time.
This complete arc happens over 12 to 16 sessions of play, depending on the group’s preferred pacing and the setbacks the retinue faces. This is enough time for characters to develop and change, and to see the kingdom slowly transform. At the same time, it gives a campaign an endpoint to play toward and a decisive finale.
The ladder of feudal power requires allies, vassals, and land. Rebel Crown’s campaign is driven by the players' decisions: which factions they forge relationships with and which holdings they seize, vassalize, or burn to the ground. Each holding the retinue adds to their domain increases their renown and provides unique resources or advantages. The drive to claim more holdings frames each sortie and provides clear stakes for the players. This structure provides both direction and choice: a singular motivation in an open sandbox of methods. 
Draft Domain Sheet
Rebel Crown includes robust GM tools, providing a framework for introducing obstacles that put the retinue’s ambitions in jeopardy without undermining their victories.  The GM uses clocks to track (and foreshadow) escalating threats within a sortie and across the campaign.  Profiles of each faction, province, and holding give context for the problems the retinue will face, with just enough detail to build on at the table.  The player-facing campaign structure is also a GM tool, in that it allows the GM to respond to the retinue's actions rather than having to worry about driving the story forward.
During a session, the Claimant and their allies choose a sortie to accomplish, then they make a few dice rolls to jump into the action of the sortie in progress. Their objective might be to form a new alliance, to conquer a holding by force, or to protect an imperiled village from the restless dead.  The PCs take actions, suffer consequences, and finish the sortie (succeed or fail). Then the retinue has downtime, during which they recover, pursue side-projects, and seek solace. After downtime, the players look for a new opportunity to pursue. This loop allows us to see the characters in moments of action and quietude, both how they fare in heated conflicts and how they recover and prepare for the next foray. 
Rebel Crown will be a professionally printed, saddle-stitched zine.  This core zine will include the rules of play and the campaign framework for reclaiming Craobhan, kingdom of moss and crag.
Rebel Crown: Serpent & Oak will provide two additional starting situations for your campaigns: new factions to contend with, and new kingdoms to reclaim. They will explore the culture and history of the other kingdoms of the Aonaicthe Empire and provide materials for making a second and third campaign feel fresh. Serpent & Oak will be a professionally printed, saddle-stitched zine.
The Boxed Set will be a custom-printed box with a linen finish and gold foil stamping. It'll be packed with both zines, along with custom Rebel Crown dice and pencils.
All rewards will ship together in August 2020.
Mockup of the Boxed Set
This is our second Kickstarter. Last ZineQuest, we introduced Goblinville, a game about broke goblins going into dangerous places to get the things they need for their ramshackle town.  Goblinville was selected to showcase at the Boston Festival of Indie Games and it's been played at conventions across the country.  You can read about it on the Indie Game Reading Club or check out the First Look by Adam Koebel.
Goblinville gave us a ton of experience to apply to Rebel Crown: from launching and running a Kickstarter, to shipping and fulfillment. This is a labor of love for us. Michael, who does the core design and writing, is a computer science teacher during the day. Eric, who does the art, layout, and development, is an artist and graphic designer. We think Rebel Crown offers something a lot of RPG groups are looking for, character-driven play threaded into a compelling campaign, and we are going to pour our hearts into this game.
Michael & Eric at PAX Unplugged
This game would not exist without John Harper’s generous licensing of Forged in the Dark games. Starting from this excellent framework allowed us to build on a design foundation we already loved.
We were also inspired (as always) by Luke Crane's The Burning Wheel, as a model for bringing character motivations to the forefront of play.
Rebel Crown's epilogue mechanics were inspired by Meguey & Vincent Baker's The King Is Dead, another game of feudal succession and divided loyalties.
We were influenced by the account of Henry Bolingbroke's rise in Shakespeare's Richard II,  by Bernard Cornwell's Saxon Stories, and by the stories of Daenerys and Stannis in A Song of Ice and Fire.
For the campaign structure, we looked to games like Crusader Kings II and Total War, where expansion always creates new opportunities and new liabilities.
We’re indebted to the playtesters who help us develop this system and to those willing to back this project.  Thanks for believing in us.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is in some ways a smaller project than our last ZineQuest. We are creating two zines rather than four, and have established affordable and effective procedures for printing and fulfillment.

There are always risks for small creative teams like us, but we have taken steps to mitigate these. We are offering a simple campaign, without stretch goals or external partners. We are doing all the writing, development, art, and layout ourselves. We’re running all international fulfillment through Shopify to limit our exposure to fluctuations in international shipping and duties costs.

We’re committed to fulfilling this project on time and communicating our progress clearly. One of the most meaningful pieces of feedback from our last campaign was that our campaign was “professional, transparent, and stress-free”. We aim to meet that bar with Rebel Crown as well.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: FONT - A new zine from Narrative Dynamics
updates.update_content:
Hi Rebel Crown backers,
We're writing because we wanted to share our new ZineQuest project with you. FONT is a GMless story game about a group of travelers who enter a strange otherworld seeking a miraculous power. Gameplay focuses on how the characters overcome the challenges they face on this journey, and how they are changed by it. FONT is inspired by other fictional forays into strange landscapes, notably Andrei Tarkovsky's Stalker and Jeff VanderMeer's Annihilation.

It's really happening! The boxes are here, surveys are in, and we're shipping out rewards to all Box Set backers on Monday. It's going to be a great weekend of putting dice and pencils into little bags.
We've started hearing from folks who have received their zines! We couldn't be more excited. We'll send the last few copies out as we get survey responses in.
We have the Serpent & Oak zines!  That means we're ready to ship out orders for those who backed for the core zines or both together.

We're excited to announce that the Serpent & Oak PDF is finally complete!  We're sending out itch.io codes in the next 24 hours.  If you don't receive one, message us and we'll make sure it gets to you.

We’ve got big updates to share this time.
The core text is with the printers and has entered production!  We should have it in hand in the next few weeks.
Dice arrived!  We’re really happy with how they turned out (especially the fine details) and we think box set folks are going to love them.

Thanks everyone for your patience with our adjusted timeline.  We've appreciated hearing from folks about their play experiences with the PDF and we know you're eager to have your zines (and boxes) in hand.

Here's what we've been up to.

When we updated our timeline in August, we were optimistic that we had the momentum to get the rest of the game out by the end of October. Since then, we have lost about a month of development time to personal crises and professional shifts. We are still working on the Serpent & Oak zine, and the print run is waiting on that. We will provide a concrete date by the end of October, but we didn't want to wait until then to share an update. Thanks for your patience and understanding.

-Eric & Michael

updates.update_userinfo: Under the Wire: The PDF Release!
updates.update_content:
We committed to releasing the PDF of Rebel Crown in August and with a huge final push, we actually did it! 
If you have been playing from the Quickstart, you'll probably notice:
New situations, factions, and NPCs for each province.  There are perils and opportunities across the kingdom and the new province map really opens the world up for the retinue's ambitions.

It's been a complicated couple of months to work on a passion project like Rebel Crown: on the one hand, having this creative outlet has made self-isolation less isolating.  On the other hand, we haven't kept the pace of development that we had planned on.
The reality is that we have to update our intended release schedule.  We've had material delays, but most of what has pushed us back has been personal: changes to our day jobs, disruptions to our work routines, and difficulty staying motivated when we can't do what we love most: playing at a table, face-to-face with our friends.

campaign.story:
This is the story of Philotes, the goddess of romantic friendship, who some call the small kiss. You know Mars, and Venus. You know Pluto. Minerva. The gods you know have all had their times as the aspect of the world. Many of them more than once. And they've had their chosen mortals doing their work.
But not Philotes. Until now.
Maybe.
Those books when you were a kid that gave you choices and page numbers for each of them? This is like that. Except remember how those choices were only ever about whether you survive and about finding the path that solved the mystery? This is not like that. 
These choices are intimate, and subjective. Philotes is trying to decide about bringing her aspect of romantic friendship upon the world. Should she talk to Venus? Can anyone help her sort it out? Is she prepared to wreck a mortal if that's what it takes? Should there be a sex scene first? Should she talk to Proserpina? It's all your decision. 
I shared my first draft with a few readers. Here's a couple of their comments.
I remember a rack of zines at the record store when I was a kid. They felt powerful and self-possessed to me, like their makers had found a form of expression that wasn't beholden to anyone else but themselves. I wanted to find my own energy like that for Zinequest and make something incautiously its own. There are scenes in We're Just Friends that are shockingly erotic. It plays with the boundaries of games and stories on multiple fronts. It's revisionist myth. The decision points are nothing like the ones you've read in classic CYOA novels. Maybe you'll make a decision and then find the character doesn't agree. In one case maybe a scene doesn't go as hoped, but you get a chance to try it a different way. No sane publisher would want anything to do with it, but as a zine it's not beholden to any sane publishers.  
If you'd like to read the first scene and its choices, click through this image of its pages.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
It's all written except for four scenes, and I have notes for those, so I don't expect to get jammed up by writer's block or something.
I've priced it with two print services, and calculated postage costs carefully. If those costs go up by a lot in the next few months, that would be a problem, but I've built in a cushion that could handle a small cost increase. I've made zines before, and I've given myself enough time to solve printing issues or whatever with this one.
So I really expect to be able to deliver We're Just Friends as promised.

campaign.story:
Drown Your Heroes.
The stories we tell are often not of gallant survivors but of the hard-pressed, star-crossed crestfallen. They are the poetry of the broken and the inhuman breakers: haunting things, deep and dark and bellowing things, unfathomable things that consume all that edges to their precipice.
Sunken is a tabletop roleplaying game about these things.
It is a tabletop roleplaying game about these things and the sea.
It is a tabletop roleplaying game about how your characters find their doom among these things while at sea.
Sunken shifts the focus of the world of Trophy onto – and below – the vast and treacherous Salt Sea, expanding "That Silent Howl" from Codex: Void into a full stand alone system that remains rooted in the mechanics of Trophy Dark.
What's It Like?
Return of the Obra Dinn, The Terror, Alien, Bioshock, Sunless Sea, Rime of the Ancient Mariner ... Sunken frames naval and sci-fi horror in a world of dark fantasy. 
How Does It Play?
As a Rooted in Trophy game, Sunken heels toward evocative storytelling over a simple framework – perfect for dramatic one-shot sessions. The original Trophy ruleset has been modified to put emphasis on the themes of dreadful ocean expeditions while keeping the overall structure lean and straightforward.
Character creation is a simple spin of the cypher: Choose your background, your job, your faction, and – if you choose to believe in that kind of thing – a patron saint.
Sunken's magic comes in the form of answered prayers to eerie saints
You might be the estranged heir of a great family, turned marine under the black-skull flag, hoping to regain the worth of your heredity. Or maybe you're secretly a Company automaton, stationed as a surgeon with that crew of vagabonds, ensuring through subterfuge that valuable secrets stay within corporate hulls.
Each voyage is divided into five tides, a series of distinct acts that uniquely raise the stakes and tension of your adventure. As you take risks to weather these tidal terrors, you'll roll dice to determine outcomes. Accumulate dice across three pools:
 The Flesh – For each skill you're able to utilize from your background and occupation, roll a die from this pool.
 The Deep – Decide how much the power of the sea drives your action, but with each die you take, increase the chances that you lose some sanity. As your mind succumbs to the depths, find yourself steered more and more by the call of the sea.
 The Heavens – An icon of hope amidst the torrent. Your fellow players can offer you divine intervention: extra effect applied to a success. If the Heavens rolls low, lose some faith in a higher power and hasten your descent into the deep.
Sunken's design heightens the feeling of navigating a capsizing character, encouraging you to pull power from the void while sliding you down an accelerating slope to your doom. 
What's Included?
Whether digital, print, or both, you get:
 Rules – A standalone nautical hack of Trophy.
 Voyages – Three in total. Inky beasts, bred with dark magic. A utopia built within the carcass of a leviathan. A fateful run-in with a cursed hive mind. 
 Shanties – Splinters of the history and lore of the Salt Sea, useful bits to fill your own voyages with.
The zine itself is:
A 8.5" x 5.5" staple-bound zine in classic zine glory, for print backers.
Gorgeous, with cover art by Gianna Meola, endpapers by Jenny Neale, and historical etchings for good measure.
Accompanied by a second mini-zine called The Drowning Scriptures – one of the campaign's stretch goals.
Sunken's layout blends historical and modern design – evoking the setting while providing clear information design. Chapters will be divided by original patterns. Note: This is mockup and not a final spread.
Which Three Voyages?
 A Covenant of Silence – A prequel/sequel/reboot of "That Silent Howl", where your crew finds itself infested with the East Passage Company's most profitable – and predatory – cargo. Find the nearest friendly face and hug them dearly.
 This Colossus Beneath – A hard-fought tip leads to the rumored dwelling of the Company's missing founder: a submerged utopia architected within the corpse of a leviathan. The timely shock of a breaching insurrection may provide opportunity to poach this belly of the beast.
 Futility's Wreck – Slogging through the icing shawl of the south, the crew of Futility find themselves not half a league from a hulking barge inhabited by cultists adorned in death's mark. This cursed band think and breathe as one, and they collect proselytes unfettered by the hardening sea.
Are There Stretch Goals?
Oh, heavens yes. 
And they've been hit by the generous backers that have come before you.
Richard Ruane (Barrow Keep) and Natalie Ash (Richter: The Rotting City) will be adding their haunting storytelling to the zine's Shanties & Lore section, adding characters, settings, and terrors in the form of found fragments.
A second mini-zine will be included with all reward levels, with a Kickstarter-exclusive print run being delivered to print backers. The Drowning Scriptures explores the eerie gothic faith of Sunken's seafarers, and includes:
More lore fragments, backgrounds, and apocryphal saints
A voyage by Madeleine Ember (Richter: The Rotting City) ... a pilgrimage following the miracles and martyrdom of a major saint
Additional artwork by cover artist Gianna Meola 
Whatever else we can pack in with the final run of backing funds
Who Is Involved?
Our core contributors represent all of America's coasts: the Great Lakes, the Gulf, the Atlantic, and Pacific.
Mike Martens – Designer, writer, creator. I'm a brand and UX copywriter transplanted to Los Angeles, applying the skills of my trade to my love for games and genre fiction.
Gianna Meola – Cover artist. Gianna is an illustrator and cartoonist, currently living and working in Brooklyn, NY. When she's not drawing she likes to volunteer with animals.
Jenny Neale – Pattern artist. Jenny is an artist and illustrator based in The Sunshine State. Shes enjoys yoga, good food and adventures in nature.
Etchings in the public domain, including work by Gustave Doré and John Flamsteed. Ocean recording in preview video by Mike Koenig (CC BY 3.0 US).

Risks and challenges
Frankly: This is my first Kickstarter, so there are certainly question marks.

That said, my decade+ background as a professional creative gives me a firm understanding of production processes and the surprises that arise in them. I have experience and support sources across the project workflow. And I've built the scale of this Kickstarter to minimize critical points of failure. 

Sunken's ruleset is complete with refinements already in testing, sped up by its reliance on the extensively tested and played Trophy system.

campaign.story:
The Game
Night Reign is a tabletop roleplaying game of stealth, guile, violence and devilry. You are a member of the Red Right Hand, a disgraced intelligence agency fighting a guerrilla war against covetous noble houses in the streets and atop the rooftops of Laenfendport, an Edwardian fantasy metropolis.
Based on Trophy Gold - which is also Kickstarting right now! - , Night Reign adapts that game's push your luck mechanics, fragile characters and costly sorcery to tales of revolution and vengeance from the shadows, with innovative card based mechanics that to push the theme and feel of stealth gameplay home. As part of Kickstarter's ZineQuest 2 campaign, you'll get a complete RPG in zine form, with a capsule setting of faux-Edwardian urban dark fantasy that will appeal to fans of Dishonored, Thief, and Blades in the Dark. 
The Zine
Night Reign is part of Kickstarter’s ZineQuest promotion, and will be available as a 48 page, b&w A5 format zine. We’re working with Biddles Books (who also printed Quietus) to produce an authentic zine feel, using a cream bookwove paper to give it a nice heavy feel for a relatively small product.
Everyone who backs at the zine level will also get a complimentary PDF version of the zine via DriveThru RPG. The PDF will be available in pure black and white for home printing, and a colour version to emulate the paper and coloured cover of the hard copy zine.
Laefendport
The scabrous, rainslick metropolis of Laefendport was mere decades previously nothing but a collection of hovels and shacks, home to scavengers who scraped a meagre existence salvaging whatever they could from the many ships dragged into the notoriously treacherous waters to its immediate east, and wrecked on shores so jagged and jutting it seems as if the very earth was reaching up in protest. Its name meant Liars Port, a reference to the treachery of both its tides and its residents.
Let me walk through the stinking alleys, to the music of drunken bearings. PJ Harvey, The Last Living Rose
The rain there, black as a moonless winter sky, viscous and inert, falls near constantly and poisons all but the hardiest, most unappealing plants, deforms and drives animals mad, and leaves anything it touches greasy and stained. For centuries, only the desperate or the touched would go anywhere near Laefendport.
Until, that is, the Eisenhart Process, an alchemical process by which the Night Rain can be filtered and made combustible. Suddenly, there was a freely available source of fuel literally falling from the sky. Free, at least, until the noble families arrived to harvest it. The city and the influence of the Nobles grew at a malignant rate, until both seemed to cover everything.
The people call the Nobles' oppressive regime The Night Reign. You're here to end it. By your hand, the Night Reign will fall. 
Stealth
You're outnumbered and outgunned, but the shadows are your greatest weapon. Night Reign uses a modified form of blackjack to model the push-your-luck, tense tactics of stealth video games, and lets you really feel the threat of being caught. 
Freedom soon will come, then we'll come from the shadows - Leonard Cohen, The Partisan
The higher your score, the more stealth tokens you'll gain, which can be used to achieve the goals of the adventure. If the deck ever runs out, you fail your mission, and a perfect score allows you to reshuffle the deck - but go bust and you'll be caught and have to fight your way out! Do you hide and wait for the perfect moment, or make a risky dash for glory? 
Guile
The riskier the action, the greater the reward. When you run up against opposition that can't be totally avoided, it's down to you and your wits to find a way around it. The wilder your plan, the quicker you'll be through, and time is always counting down. 
Threw my bad fortune off the top of a tall building. PJ Harvey, Good Fortune
But the more cautious you are, the more information you'll get before you make the draw. Play it your way!
Violence
Sometimes, things are going to get nasty. Whether you've been caught, or you're more about spilling blood than hugging the shadows, members of the Red Right Hand didn't get that epithet for nothing. Simple to run, but tactically deep, Night Reign's combat system is all about reading your opponent's moves, choosing when to defend and when to strike, and can run anything from a single master swordsman to a rioting mob in just a few rounds. 
On a gathering storm comes a tall handsome man, in a dusty black coat with a red right hand - Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds, Red Right Hand
But be quick - the longer a fight takes, the more chaos tokens you'll accrue, and the harder it will be to go unnoticed - and the messier and darker things will get in Laefendport.
Devilry
Laefendport does not traffic with gods. The sea swallows everything that dares come near, and the sky pisses down black tar onto the land. If ever anyone prayed to a god here, their prayers were demonstrably not answered. Instead, Laefendport has the Sisters. They are not things to worship, they are things to blame misfortune on, to curse, to avoid. If you mutter their names in a prayer, it is to ask that they overlook you for another day.
Well, if you're gonna dine with the cannibals, sooner or later, darling, you're gonna get eaten. - Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds, Cannibal Hymn
At any time, players can draw from the Sisters deck to create an unnatural effect - bursting into a flock of crows, filling a room full of impenetrable shadows, or summoning a swarm of rats to do their bidding, amongst other macabre powers, and gain an automatic 10. But draw the card that corresponds to the sister whose power you are leaching, and they'll turn their eye on you.

UNLOCKED! We'll be getting full page illustrations from Kasha Mika to complement their awesome existing spot illustrations.
UNLOCKED! A new digital scenario for Night Reign from Diana, aka Superdillen, host of the Fem NPC YouTube channel and the Femsplained podcast, author of the 5e Neverland Setting and creator of those D&D TikToks you retweeted!
Here's the pitch for Diana's scenario The Bootleggers...
"During times of hardship, the desperate have sought to buy harvested night rain from unwanted sources. Often those that do find themselves in possession of a poorly filtered and unstable substance, resulting in poisonings, explosions and worse. Rumors have made it to your ears of some peddlers that must be dispatched - and their source of night reign redistributed to the ones that they sought to take advantage of."
UNLOCKED!  A new digital scenario from Sabine V, one of the awesome writers on the core Trophy RPG. Here's the pitch for Sabine's scenario "The Firstborn is Dead":
"One of the prominent noble patriarchs has died, and much to the disgust and distress of his family, without leaving a will, or a (legal) heir. But scuttlebutt would have it that one of The Red Right Hand's own is his bastard... or perhaps even a legitimate heir as he was rumoured to have wed in secret as a foolish young man. Now all you need to do is break into the Palaces of Justice, one of the most heavily guarded buildings in Laefendport, to get the documents that prove it..." 
UNLOCKED! We'll be getting a digital scenario"Down by the Water" from Natalie Ash, winner of the Trophy incursion contest. writer on the core Trophy RPGand one half of Ember and Ash!

You might not be able to take off with a whole ship’s worth, but even a few crates can make a difference. Fortunately, you know a dock worker who owes you a favor."

Ruled by Night - sinisterbeard.com
Our final stretch goal at £6,000!  If we reach £6,000, I'll be working with Evan Whakahau (@maori_nerd on Twitter) to create a full alternate setting as a digital supplement for Night Reign, inspired by one of my favourite stealth video games, The Mark of Kri, and Evan's knowledge of Māori culture: Mohtuhoarri, an archipelago on the other side of the world from Laefendport.
The Team
Oli Jeffery - Game Design and Layout
Oli is a games designer with a taste for the macabre. He successfully Kickstarted and delivered Quietus, the roleplaying game of melancholy horror, in 2019. Oli wants to bring the feel and the mechanics of stealth video games to tabletop RPGs and Night Reign is his answer to that.
Oli will also be handling the layout for the book, and is an accomplished graphic designer focusing on RPGs. His layout work can be seen in Quietus, Legacy: Life Among the Ruins 2E, Dust, Fog & Glowing Embers and the first two volumes of The Gauntlet's Codex zine.  Chat with him about RPGs and horror movies at @ojeffery.
Kasha Mika - Illustrations
Kasha Mika will handle interior illustrations for the zine. Their striking limited colour-palette artwork can be seen in previous Sinister Beard Games products Quietus and Videostore, and retweeted across the internet. They enjoy listening to pop-punk music and podcasts, playing tabletop games with friends, discussing gender and sexuality in media, and making art constantly. Check out their work at  kashaprinzing.art.
Harriet Moulton - Cover Art
Harriet Moulton has produced the game's evocative cover art. Harriet's main focus is art and stories about older lesbian characters. She currently resides in Bristol, England and you could not pay her to go live in the idyllic countryside again where she spent the first 18 years of her life. See her portfolio at harrietmoulton.co.uk for more.
Misha Bushyager - Sensitivity Editing
Misha is a longtime gamer and designer working on making sure the next generation of geeks sees themselves represented. She's a panelist, writer, editor, proofreader, and sensitivity reader for tabletop RPGs and larps. Misha is one of the founders of New Agenda Publishing and a curator for More Seats at the Table. Her writing was recently seen in Fate of Cthulhu.
Funding
At the core level, you'll be funding: illustrations from Kasha to help bring the world to life; sensitivity reading from Misha Bushyager, and cover the cost of printing and postage. In short, you'll be paying to make the best version of the book that we can.
Funding for the cover art was provided by The Gauntlet. Thanks to them for the loan and for the licence on Trophy that makes this game possible.
Rooted in Trophy - Fulfilled by DriveThru RPG
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
In line with the ZineQuest spirit, I’ve tried to keep this campaign as low risk as possible. It’s a short, low cost run. All stretch goals aside from the additional full page art will be digital only so there’s no danger of holding the project up.
This is our second Kickstarter after successfully funding and delivering Quietus. All costs should be covered by the budget of the Kickstarter, and I've focused on paying the people I've commissioned before myself.

Printing and distribution will be handled by Biddles Books and KixTo, both of whom I have a good relationship with and who have delivered excellently in the past. PDFs will be handled through DriveThru.

The rules of the game have been written and playtested, but the full text of the zine will be written post Kickstarter. I believe I’ve budgeted enough time to account for this in my delivery goals, based on past delivered projects and commissions.

The UK is currently undergoing some political upheaval as the result of leaving the EU at the end of last month. Fluctuations in the price of the pound are possible and almost all other staff working on the project work outside of the UK. I've allocated a contingency fund in the budget to account for this.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The villagers of Edmund Valley work tirelessly as the overbearing sun scorches the drought-dried land. Though the drought has made things difficult for the people, they have hope, because they know that when the sun reaches its peak on the hottest day of the year, they arrive, and they bring miracles with them.
Procession is a game about monsters and miracles. It is a game about imagining a village, and then making it better through unconventional means. It is a game about empathizing with bizarre beings. You do not play any single character, but embody the town of Edmund Valley as a whole and the bizarre creatures that pass through it.
Procession is a short single-player game, and is inspired by both Avery Alder's The Quiet Year and Takuma Okada's Alone series. The only thing required to play the game is a deck of cards, but I would recommend using paper and pencil as well to record your thoughts. The game is 8 pages long including the front and back cover, and features Wendel Dietterlin's Renaissance art, Procession of Monstrous Figures.
Due to differences in available printers, US versions of the zine will be printed on letter-sized paper and UK versions of the zine will be printed on A4 paper. If you do not live in either the US or the UK, the PDF reward will come with printing instructions if you want to print your own copy!
Stretch Goals!
Procession is now getting stretch goals! These stretch goals will unlock new PDFs to add more variety to the game! Backers at any level will receive all unlocked stretch goal content! Stretch goal rewards will be delivered at a later date.
Stretch Goal 1 ($600): Procession Expanded
Procession Expanded doubles the number of events that can happen during the Procession, with new rules to allow you to play with two suits of cards or stick with a single suit and choose one of two options each time you draw.
Stretch Goal 2 ($750): Four Suit Procession
Four Suit Procession adds new events that can happen during the Procession, allowing you to play with a full deck of cards instead of just one suit!
The People Behind Procession
Tyler Magruder is a nonbinary tabletop game designer and writer. The guiding principle behind their game design is finding a way to make the gameplay resonate with the themes and stories being told. Also they just really like monsters. You can find their work on itchio and Patreon, and their thoughts on Twitter.
Chloe Montgomery will be handling UK printing and shipping!
Wendel Dietterlin the Younger was a German artist who worked in the 17th Century. No portrait of him exists to my knowledge so I had to use his art to represent him instead.

campaign.story:
Under The Floorboards is a tabletop roleplaying game for 2-5 players about tiny people living in a giant, hostile world, inspired by The Borrowers. The focus of the game is very story-driven, with an emphasis on collaborative storytelling and worldbuilding over stats and crunch.
Build your family and the house in which they live, then embark on an expedition into the land of giants in order to collect the things you need to survive - without being seen.
The game uses a simple 2d6 system for conflict resolution and an easy-to-pick-up story-building system to help GMs build engaging scenes on the fly.
Under The Floorboards is a low-prep game designed for one shot play but with tools to enable campaign play over multiple sessions. The game provides locations, hazards, and tools to quickly design your own content to keep surprising your players, and is perfect for convention play or to keep on your shelf for game nights when your whole group can't be there.
The zine contains:
All the rules you need to create characters and play Under The Floorboards
10 unique locations for Expeditions - now upgraded to 16 locations after hitting the first stretch goal! 
12 Enemies and Challenges to populate your Locations
Tools to create your own Locations, Enemies, and Challenges
Guidelines for campaigns and extended play 
Test print of Under The Floorboards. Jewelry, buttons, flowers and stuff not included in your pledge, obviously. The typos won't be there either.
The zine will be a 44-page, A5 saddle-stitched booklet printed in black ink on 130gsm silk interior pages - now upgraded to 160gsm natural paper after hitting the second stretch goal! - with a sturdy heavyweight cover in a classic mustard yellow intended to evoke beloved clothbound books from childhood.
Stretch goals will unlock additional pages, as well as increasing the quality of the interior pages to 160gsm natural paper for a real premium finish.
Under The Floorboards ships anywhere in the world for a flat fee of £3, which will be collected through Kickstarter. There will be no need for you to enter extra information or payments to external services.
Who are these little people and where do they live?
The game begins as players collaboratively build a family of Floorboard Folk, describing their relationships to one another and building the space that they call home. 
The players then decide what they need so badly that they are going to plan an Expedition into the land of the giants to get it.
What does an Expedition look like?
Expeditions are divided into three phases - Scouting, Borrowing, and The Return.
In the Scouting phase, players collectively describe the Location that the Expedition takes place in. They will identify their goal and the hazards in the way of attaining it, and devise a plan of action. A simple system helps the GM determine how accurately the Scout remembered the Location, and how Lucky the group will be.
In the Borrowing phase, the players travel away from their home to the Location they scouted in the first phase. This is where the story truly comes alive. The GM uses the results of the Scouting phase to introduce Complications and Dangers to the Expedition, keeping the players on their toes as their plan tries to unravel. Success depends on how well they have prepared, and their ability to react to the ever-changing land of the giants.
During the Expedition characters will have to rely on their own wits and skills as well as each other, and will forge bonds and live through tales that will become the stuff of Floorboard Folk legend.
The final phase, The Return, sees the characters put the Expedition behind them and head home. This is the time to reflect on what happened, further develop the bonds between your characters, and slowly begin to build the legend of your family. And, if you feel up to it, now may well be the time to begin planning the next Expedition.
Where are these Locations?
The Locations of Under The Floorboards are the mundane spaces that we giants take for granted, made fantastic when seen from the perspective of the Floorboard Folk.
Under The Floorboards comes with a set of locations designed to test the wits of your players and build epic stories on a tiny scale. Traverse the teetering spines and towering cliff-faces of The Library, where one wrong move could send you tumbling to your death on the hard floor below; sneak through the cramped tunnels behind the Skirting Board, where rats and spiders lurk in dark corners waiting to pounce; or brave the ashen coals of the Fireplace, with no way of knowing when they might erupt into flame once more.
The game comes with ten Locations within the house of the giants, and stretch goals will help unlock a set of six new dangerous spaces outside in The Garden.
£1500 - Six New Locations
This goal has been reached, adding 6 Locations over 12 pages to the zine! 
Some of the new locations are:
 The Bird House: A wooden bird house and bath in the middle of the garden. It's high and it's exposed, and birds come at go at regular intervals - birds who would love a tiny person as a snack. 
 The Bone Yard: A burial ground at the back of the garden for the snacks and toys of the dog the giants keep in the house. Something has been taken from you and buried here. Do you dare retrieve it?
 The Bramble: Beneath the hedges is a tangle of piercing thorns and choking weeds, where danger is hidden until it is right on top of you. But the giants drop things, and they often end up here. Does the risk outweigh the reward?
£2000 - Thicker Paper
This goal has been reached, upgrading the zine to gorgeous natural paper throughout!
Rather than 120gsm silk, the interior pages will be printed on 160gsm natural paper for a classier, more satisfying finish.
£3000 - More Art
We'll add more interior artwork to the zine. Most of this will be added to the Location pages.
Chris Bissette (Twitter: @pangalactic) is an ENnie-nominated TTRPG designer and musician from Manchester, UK. He has been playing RPGs and story games almost as long as he has been reading and is passionate about shared storytelling and building weird, surreal worlds.
He is best known for his blog Loot The Room. He has written for Onyx Path Publishing (Yugman's Guide To Ghelspad), is a bestselling DMs Guild creator, and publishes small games on itch.io.
Madeleine Ember (Twitter: @MadeleineEmber)  is a writer and illustrator living in Washington state, US. She's also half of Ember & Ash - a small press publishing original TTRPG content. She lives with the love of her life, Natalie Ash, and their two delightful cats.
